Some Western authorities disaggregate into two main components, the altruistic and the narcissistic. This view is represented in the works of [[Scott Peck]], whose works in the field of applied psychology explored the definitions of love and evil. Peck maintains that love is a combination of the"'concern for the spiritual growth of another", and simple narcissism.<ref name="peck">{{cite book | title=The Road Less Travelled | id=ISBN 0-671-25067-1 | last=Peck | first=Scott | publisher=Simon & Schuster | year=1978 | page=169}}</ref> In combination, love is an ''activity'', not simply a feeling.
  +   +
Helen Fisher is conducting a scientific experiment in which she tests the brain activities of those who are shown a picture of their loved ones using an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging). She then compares this result with the brain scan of those who are shown a picture of someone to which they are not attracted. Though her research is not complete, she thinks that particular parts of the brain "light up" during the first brain scan.
